raw_comment:
1. I noticed that regardless of income, legacy applicants were admitted significantly higher than those without legacy status. Furthermore, even with the highest income the likelihood of students being admitted is slightly over 2x which pales in comparison to legacy students with a 99.9 parent income rate.
2. I wonder how income factors into the school's decisions as to who is admitted and who isn't. Does the number of legacy students being admitted suggest nepotism? What makes legacy students better applicants than non-legacy students? Does it matter what the alumni did at these schools for the legacy students to get admitted?
3. This relates to me and my community as being from an urban community it means that a number of my classmates/peers have not had the same fortune of being legacy students/having parents that were alumni thus making admission that much harder for those already at a disadvantage for something completely out of their control (with parental/guardian income also being completely out of these students control). 
4. Nepotism at Ivy, Advantages Not Even Money Could Buy!
ace_sentences: I noticed a pattern in admissions.
Legacy applicants were admitted at a significantly higher rate than non-legacy applicants.
This difference existed regardless of income.
Even at the highest income level, the likelihood of admission was slightly more than 2 times.
This likelihood was lower than the likelihood for legacy applicants whose parents had a 99.9 income percentile.
I wonder how income affects the school's admission decisions.
I ask whether the admission of many legacy students suggests nepotism.
I ask what makes a legacy student a better applicant than a non-legacy student.
I ask whether the actions of alumni at these schools affect the admission of their children.
I come from an urban community.
Many of my classmates are not legacy students.
Many parents of my classmates are not alumni of these schools.
This situation makes admission harder for these classmates.
Legacy status is out of the control of these classmates.
Parental or guardian income is out of the control of these classmates.
The headline is: Nepotism at Ivy, Advantages Not Even Money Could Buy!
